record.field: First Aid responders should pay attention to self-protection and use the recommended protective clothing (chemical resistant gloves, splash protection).
If potential for exposure exists refer to Section 8 for specific personal protective equipment.
Under ordinary workplace conditions: No special measures required.
Show safety data sheet to the doctor in attendance.
Immediate medical attention is not required.
If effects occur, consult a physician.
If breathing stops, give artificial respiration.
Adopt adequate precautions for the rescuer.
Wash with plenty of water or water and soap.
Immediately flush skin with plenty of water for at least 15 minutes while removing contaminated clothing.
Seek medical attention if symptoms occur or irritation persists.
Suitable emergency safety shower facility should be immediately available.
If the product is dry: wipe all residues with a cloth.
Rinse immediately with plenty of water.
Wash eyes immediately and continuously with water for 30 minutes.
Remove contact lenses after the first 5 minutes and continue washing.
Remove contact lenses, if present and easy to do.
Seek medical attention immediately, preferably from an ophthalmologist.
Seek medical advice in case of continuous irritation.
Wash eyes en route if possible.
Suitable emergency eye wash facility should be immediately available.
Do not rub to avoid further damage to the cornea.
Give one cup (8 ounces or 240 ml) of water or milk if available and transport to a medical facility.
Give as much water to drink as possible.
Do not give anything by mouth unless the person is fully conscious.
If effects occur, consult a physician.
Do not give anything to drink.
All extinguishing agents can be used.
Produces at low oxygen level: acetic acid.
Exposure to combustion products may be a hazard to health.
Over pressure can be created in containers exposed to fire with danger of explosion.
Sulphur oxides (SOx) may be released when heating above the decomposition temperature.
Reacts with water releasing large amounts of carbon dioxide which may cause pressure build-up in confined spaces.
Fire residues and contaminated fire extinguishing water must be disposed of in accordance with local regulations.
Use extinguishing measures that are appropriate to local circumstances and the surrounding environment.
Use water spray to cool unopened containers.
Collect contaminated fire extinguishing water separately.
This must not be discharged into drains.
Remove undamaged containers from fire area if it is safe to do so.
Evacuate the personnel away from the fumes.
In the event of fire, wear self-contained breathing apparatus.
Follow safe handling advice and personal protective equipment recommendations.
Stop the leak if the operation is safe.
Keep people not involved in emergency intervention away from the area affected by the spreading.
Provide adequate ventilation of the premises affected by the spreading.
It may be effective to slowly dilute the spread substance with water.
If material is released indicate risk of slipping.
Avoid contact with skin and eyes.
Discharge into the environment must be avoided.
Prevent the product from entering sewers, surface water, groundwater.
Prevent further leakage or spillage if safe to do so.
Prevent spreading over a wide area (e.g. by containment or oil barriers).
Retain and dispose of contaminated wash water.
Local authorities should be advised if significant spillages cannot be contained.
Soak up with inert absorbent material.
Suck up the leaked product into a suitable container.
Clean up remaining materials from spill with suitable absorbant.
Provide sufficient ventilation of the place affected by the leak
Local or national regulations may apply to releases and disposal of this material, as well as those materials and items employed in the cleanup of releases.
You will need to determine which regulations are applicable.
For large spills, provide dyking or other appropriate containment to keep material from spreading.
If dyked material can be pumped.

Clean up dry the product using methods that do not cause the dispersion of the dry product into the air, for example: - suction cleaners (portable industrial strength, equipped with an effective air particle filter (HEPA filter) or some other equivalent technique) - floorcloths, damp brushes or hosepipe with spray attachment (set to "fine spray" in order to avoid dispersing the product into the air).

If the product cannot be removed dry using a suction cleaner or made wet, make sure that staff responsible for sweeping it up dry wear appropriate individual protection equipment and that further dispersion of dust is prevented.
Place the recovered product in a closed container.
Wash contaminated area with large amounts of water.
Sections 13 and 15 of this SDS provide information regarding certain local or national requirements.
Pick up and transfer to properly labelled containers.
After cleaning, flush away traces with water.
Do not get on skin or clothing.
Do not breathe vapours or spray mist.
Avoid contact with skin and eyes.
Take care to prevent spills, waste and minimize release to the environment.
Handle in accordance with good industrial hygiene and safety practice.
See Engineering measures under EXPOSURE CONTROLS/PERSONAL PROTECTION section.
Do not eat, drink or smoke during use.
Remove contaminated clothing and protective equipment before entering eating areas.
Spilled substance increases risk of slipping.
No special precautions against fire and explosion required.
Keep away from sources of ignition.
Take precautionary measures against static discharges.
Keep only in the original container.
Keep the containers closed, in a well-ventilated place, away from direct sunlight.
Store in accordance with the particular national regulations.
Keep closed and in a cool and dry atmosphere.
Keep away from heat, sparks and open flames.
Avoid contact with water or humidity.
Non acid-proof metals (such as aluminium, copper and iron).
Use engineering controls to maintain airborne level below exposure limit requirements or guidelines.
If there are no applicable exposure limit requirements or guidelines, use only with adequate ventilation.
Local exhaust ventilation may be necessary for some operations.
Ensure adequate ventilation of the rooms.
Chemical goggles should be consistent with EN 166 or equivalent.
It is recommended to wear airtight protective goggles.
Use chemical resistant gloves classified under Standard EN374: Protective gloves against dangerous chemicals and micro-organisms.

Examples of preferred glove barrier materials include: Butyl rubber. Neoprene. Nitrile/butadiene rubber ("nitrile" or "NBR"). Ethyl vinyl alcohol laminate ("EVAL"). Polyvinyl chloride ("PVC" or "vinyl"). Viton.
Examples of preferred glove barrier materials include: Butyl rubber, Neoprene, NBR, PVC.
Examples of acceptable glove barrier materials include: Natural rubber ("latex").
Avoid gloves made of: Polyvinyl alcohol ("PVA").
When prolonged or frequently repeated contact may occur, a glove with a protection class of 6 (breakthrough time greater than 480 minutes according to EN 374) is recommended.
When only brief contact is expected, a glove with a protection class of 3 or higher (breakthrough time greater than 60 minutes according to EN 374) is recommended.

Glove thickness alone is not a good indicator of the level of protection a glove provides against a chemical substance as this level of protection is also highly dependent on the specific composition of the material that the glove is fabricated from.
The thickness of the glove must, depending on model and type of material, generally be more than 0.35 mm to offer sufficient protection for prolonged and frequent contact with the substance.
As an exception to this general rule it is known that multilayer laminate gloves may offer prolonged protection at thicknesses less than 0.35 mm.
Other glove materials with a thickness of less than 0.35 mm may offer sufficient protection when only brief contact is expected.
Use protective clothing chemically resistant to this material.
Wear professional long-sleeved work clothes and safety footwear (category S2 or superior).
Selection of specific items such as face shield, boots, apron, or full body suit will depend on the task.
Use of protective gloves is recommended when handling the material.
Respiratory protection should be worn when there is a potential to exceed the exposure limit requirements or guidelines.

If there are no applicable exposure limit requirements or guidelines, wear respiratory protection when adverse effects, such as respiratory irritation or discomfort have been experienced, or where indicated by your risk assessment process.
Use the following CE approved air-purifying respirator: Particulate filter, type P2 (meeting standard EN 143).
Wear a protective mask during spray application.
See SECTION 7: Handling and storage and SECTION 13: Disposal considerations for measures to prevent excessive environmental exposure during use and waste disposal.
Not classified as a reactivity hazard.
Product slowly corrodes copper, aluminum, zinc and galvanized surfaces.
Reaction with peroxides may result in violent decomposition of peroxide possibly creating an explosion.
Aqueous solutions react with light metals, e.g. aluminum, with the formation of hydrogen.
In contact with reactive metals (as steel to carbon & aluminum) may produce hydrogen.
At high temperature formation of phosphorous oxides.
Can react with strong oxidizing agents.
In normal conditions of use and storage no dangerous reactions are foreseeable.
The product can react with acids.
It can react with aluminum, zinc, tin and their alloys to produce hydrogen.
It can react with aluminum to produce hydrogen.
Humid conditions during storage may cause lump formation and loss of product quality.
Prolonged skin contact is unlikely to result in absorption of harmful amounts.
Based on available data, the classification criteria are not met
Due to the pH of the material, it is assumed that exposure will cause skin burns.
Due to the pH of the material, it is assumed that exposure may cause skin irritation.
Based on the available data a clinically relevant skin irritation hazard is not expected.
Based on available data, the classification criteria are not met
Due to the pH of the material, it is assumed that exposure may cause severe irritation with corneal injury which may result in permanent impairment of vision, even blindness.
Due to the pH of the material, it is assumed that exposure may cause severe eye damage.
Based on the available data a clinically relevant eye irritation hazard is not expected.
Based on available data, the classification criteria are not met
May cause an allergic skin reaction.
For skin sensitization: No relevant data found.
For respiratory sensitization: No relevant data found.
Based on the available data a sensitization reaction is not expected from this product.
In vitro genetic toxicity studies were negative.
Animal genetic toxicity studies were negative.
Based on known data a significant mutagenic potential may be excluded.
Based on available data, the classification criteria are not met
For this endpoint no toxicological test data is available for the whole product.
Based on available data, the classification criteria are not met
In animal studies, did not interfere with reproduction.
For this endpoint no toxicological test data is available for the whole product.
Based on available data, the classification criteria are not met
Material is not classified as a respiratory irritant; however, upper respiratory tract irritation or corrosivity may be expected.
In animals, effects have been reported on the following organs:
For this endpoint no toxicological test data is available for the whole product.
Based on available data, the classification criteria are not met.
Based on physical properties, not likely to be an aspiration hazard.
Based on available data, the classification criteria are not met
Not classified (Technical impossibility to obtain the data / the product is not used as an aerosol)
Do not dump into any sewers, on the ground, or into any body of water.
This product, when being disposed of in its unused and uncontaminated state should be treated as a hazardous waste according to EC Directive 2008/98/EC.
Any disposal practices must be in compliance with all national and provincial laws and any municipal or local by-laws governing hazardous waste.
For used, contaminated and residual materials additional evaluations may be required.
The definitive assignment of this material to the appropriate EWC group and thus its proper EWC code will depend on the use that is made of this material.
Contact the authorized waste disposal services.
Containers may be recycled or re-used.
Dispose of according to regulations by incineration in a special waste incinerator.
Small quantities may be disposed of by incineration in an approved facility.
Completely discharge containers (no tear drops, no powder rest, scraped carefully).
Recommended cleaning agent for packaging: water.
Product residues to be considered non-hazardous waste.
No expected damaging effects to aquatic organisms.
According to current knowledge adverse effects on water purification plants are not expected.
The product is to be considered as dangerous for the environment .
Is harmful to aquatic organisms with long-term negative effects for the aquatic environment.
Elimination by adsorption to activated sludge.
Passes OECD test(s) for ready biodegradability.
This substance/mixture does not meet the PBT criteria of REACH regulation, annex XIII.
This substance/mixture does not meet the vPvB criteria of REACH regulation, annex XIII.
According to present knowledge no adverse influence to environment expected.
